operation.descriptionCdata:
2c97f8cb-80a7-4881-b991-6436f5dcd892.description=
Runs multiple Shell commands by creating a SSH shell and checking output against regular expressions.

Inputs\:
    host - The hostname or IP address of the target machine.
    port - The port number for SSH protocol.
Default value\: 22
    username - Name of the account on the target machine.
    password - The password for the username. When using a private key file or a private key string, this input will be used as the passphrase for the file or string. For security reasons it is recommend to provide this input and protect the private key when using the 'privateKeyData' and the 'privateKeyFile' inputs.
    proxyHost - The proxy server used to access the remote machine.
    proxyPort - The proxy server port. Default\: 8080. Valid values\: -1 and numbers greater than 0.
    proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy.
    proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the proxyUsername input value.
    privateKeyFile - The absolute path to the private key file (OpenSSH type) on the machine where the worker is. For security reasons it is recommend that the private key be protected by a passphrase that should be provided through the 'password' input.
    privateKeyData – A string representing the private key (OpenSSH type) used for authenticating the user. This string is usually the content of a private key file. The 'privateKeyData' and the 'privateKeyFile' inputs are mutually exclusive. For security reasons it is recommend that the private key be protected by a passphrase that should be provided through the 'password' input.
    knownHostsPolicy - The policy used for managing known_hosts file. We recommend to use a "strict" policy so as to verify the host key against a local file containing known, trustworthy machines. If you choose "allow" or "add" policy then you will connect to the server without any verification. If there is a Man-In-The-Middle attack then you will be connected to a fake server and the SSH commands that you send will go through that fake server. 
Valid values\:  
allow\=It will permit the connection to any hosts. 
strict\=It will permit the connection only to the hosts specified in known_hosts file. 
add\=It will permit the connection to any hosts, if the host is not in the known_hosts file it will be added. 
Default value\: strict
    allowedCiphers - A comma separated list of ciphers that will be used in the client-server handshake mechanism when the connection is created. Check the notes section for security concerns regarding your choice of ciphers. The default value will be used even if the input is not added to the operation.
Default value\: aes128-ctr,aes128-cbc,aes192-ctr,aes192-cbc,aes256-ctr,aes256-cbc
    command - The commands to execute. This should be made up of 'send ' and 'expect ' statements separated by newlineCharacters.
    characterSet - The characterSet name for input stream encoding from the target machine.
Examples\: SJIS, EUC-JP, UTF-8
Default value\: UTF-8
    newlineCharacters - The character sequence to send as the enter key being pressed after each 'send' statement as the send expect script is processed in the command input. Either '\r\n' '\n' '\r' or a comma delimited list of ASCII escape sequences.
    timeout - Time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete.
Default value\: 90000
    connectTimeout - Time in milliseconds to wait for the connection to be made.
Default value\: 10000
    keepAlive - Time in milliseconds to wait between keep alive packets that are sent to the server. If the value of this input is 0, no keep alive packets will be sent during the execution.
Valid values\: 0, any value between 1000 and 86400000
Default value\: 0
    sessionId - Identifier of a shared SSH shell session created by SSH Shell Logon. Instead of creating a new SSH shell session this one will be used if specified. 

Results\:
    returnResult - The primary output.
    STDOUT - The standard output of the command(s).
    visualized - The output of the command in XML format.
    TimedOut - Is set to "true" if the value set in the "timeout" input has elapsed and the command timed out.

Responses\:
    success - The operation was executed successfully.
    failure - The connection could not be established or the commands are invalid for this operation (not for target machine's shell).

Notes\:

The operation should always be used as a set like  [SSH Shell Logon] -> [SSH Shell] -> [SSH Shell Logoff] 

1. The following commands are supported\:
1.1. Send a Shell command.
    send 
Examples\: send ls
1.2. Send a char given by ASCII code.
    sendChar 
Examples\: sendChar 32
1.3. Match the entire previous command output against the regex.
    expect 
Examples\: expect (.*)Desktop(.*)
1.4. The entire previous command output ends with the given text.
    expectEndsWith 
1.5. Match the last line from the previous command output against the regex.
    expectLastLine 
1.6. Fail on the success of the expect command\: expect, expectEndsWith or expectLastLine.
    errorOn 
1.7. If the expect command is successful then the operation will always execute the send command.
    always 
    on 
Examples\: 
Single line output\: always sendChar 121
                           on expect (.*)Press y to continue(.*)
Multiple line output example 1\: always sendChar 121
                             	 on expect (?s)(.*)Press y to continue(.*)
Multiple line output example 2\: always sendChar 121
                             	 on expectLastLine (.*)Press y to continue(.*)
1.8. Use a different timeout for this send command\: send, sendChar.
    wait  
1.9. Use a different timeout for this expect command\: expect, expectEndsWith or expectLastLine.
    wait  
1.10. (.*)does not match by default new lines so add the (?s) flag at the beginning of regex. This flag means "make the dot metacharacter match new lines, too".
     expect (?s)(.*)Aug(.*)

2. Hidden inputs\:
    knownHostsPath -  Specifies the path to the known_hots file on the running server.
Default value\: /.ssh/known_hosts
Examples\: /home/admin/.ssh/known_hosts
    readTimeout - Time in milliseconds to wait for reading and then matching the output with the regex from expect command.
Default value\: 20000
3. In order to use private keys with different encryption types (ex.\: aes256-cbc) needs to be updated the /java/lib/security/local_policy.jar JAR file with one that accept all security policies (ex.\: http\://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jce-7-download-432124.html). After update you must restart the Studio or Central service.
4. The operation supports connections through HTTP proxy with username and password authentication.
5. For security reasons, HPE does not recommend the use of outdated or vulnerable ciphers. Therefore "arcfour" cihpers should be avoided because they do not provide confidentiality for data in transit and using them can lead to information leakage.
Arcfour is vulnerable to the following attacks\: Fluhrer, Mantin and Shamir attack, Klein's attack, Royal Holloway attack, Bar-mitzvah attack and NOMORE attack.
operation.name: SSH Shell
